update.description:
Add habitat model for task 3 and integrate it into the world.

![hab1.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2915144268-hab1.png)

* There's a habitat SDF model mostly for reference and to have the model directory structure
* The `habitat.erb` file is where the collisions and the whole model structure are actually generated from
* Detailed simple collision shapes for the stairs and rails
* Simple collision shapes for floors and walls

    ![hab2.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1709277528-hab2.png)

* There are two models, the `habitat_base` is a static model consisting of all the visuals except for the entrance door

* The `habitat_door` model is not static and consists of the door and the valve. It has 3 joints:
    * A fixed "lock" joint which will be removed once the valve is turned
    * A revolute joint for the valve, with the same range of friction as the satellite wheels

        ![habdoor.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/743741129-habdoor.gif)

    * A hinge joint with the world about which the door opens. If you want to try pushing the door, you can manually remove the lock joint from the world. The friction on the hinge helps the door remain open.

        ![habdoor2.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3570344327-habdoor2.gif)

        I tried pushing it with Val and it looks reasonable:

        ![habdoor4.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1139374490-habdoor4.gif)

* Moved the table to be inside the habitat and added a point light inside so it's not very dark:

    ![hab6.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3009515305-hab6.png)

* Modified the heightmap so that there's room for the habitat (humans are always changing planets, right?)
update.title: Task 3: Habitat model

update.title: Task 3: Habitat model

content.raw:
Ok, take a look at commit e82ec5e*, according to my experiments, this places the effort needed to turn the valve between 3 and 4.5 times the one needed to turn the satellite.

It's worth mentioning that the satellite doesn't have damping, so the lower friction here compensates for the damping introduced in order to make the valve stabilize quickly.

\* when I say satellite, I mean door
content.html:
Ok, take a look at commit e82ec5e*, according to my experiments, this places the effort needed to turn the valve between 3 and 4.5 times the one needed to turn the satellite.

It's worth mentioning that the satellite doesn't have damping, so the lower friction here compensates for the damping introduced in order to make the valve stabilize quickly.

* when I say satellite, I mean door

update.title: Task 3: Habitat model

content.raw: I agree with your general reasoning here.  I think 10 times harder might be a bit much, though.  What do you think about making it 2 or 3 times harder?  It will have to be less damped, but that isn't as important.
content.html: I agree with your general reasoning here. I think 10 times harder might be a bit much, though. What do you think about making it 2 or 3 times harder? It will have to be less damped, but that isn't as important.

content.raw:
Unfortunately I think that teleoperating Val with the keyboard to open the valve would take too much time :( . My current reasoning is:

* Teams have been playing with the satellite for a while and haven't complained about it being too stiff - so let's assume that is a good reference.
* Applying 100N torque to a satellite wheel rotates it by 0.091 rad
* Applying 100N torque to the door valve rotates it by 0.0083 rad, so the valve is about 10 times harder to turn than the satellite wheels
* I'd expect in real life for the door valve to be harder than the satellite wheels
* The door is on task 3 (i.e. it's worth more points), so it's expected that it is harder to complete

What do you think? Is an order of magnitude too much?
content.html:
Unfortunately I think that teleoperating Val with the keyboard to open the valve would take too much time :( . My current reasoning is:

  • Teams have been playing with the satellite for a while and haven't complained about it being too stiff - so let's assume that is a good reference.
  • Applying 100N torque to a satellite wheel rotates it by 0.091 rad
  • Applying 100N torque to the door valve rotates it by 0.0083 rad, so the valve is about 10 times harder to turn than the satellite wheels
  • I'd expect in real life for the door valve to be harder than the satellite wheels
  • The door is on task 3 (i.e. it's worth more points), so it's expected that it is harder to complete

What do you think? Is an order of magnitude too much?

content.raw: That's a lot better when applying direct torque to it.  Did you get a chance to test that Val can still reasonably open it?  I still haven't been able to get Val to stand up properly, so I can't test it right now.  Other than that, I think this is pretty good.
content.html: That's a lot better when applying direct torque to it. Did you get a chance to test that Val can still reasonably open it? I still haven't been able to get Val to stand up properly, so I can't test it right now. Other than that, I think this is pretty good.

content.raw: Added some damping to the valve joint on 28866c6
content.html: Added some damping to the valve joint on 28866c6

update.title: Task 3: Habitat model

content.raw:
About moving the models around, it should be fine, because competitors are not expected to do this during the competition. The models which are not responding to gravity have been marked as "static". This means the robot can't knock them over, and it also eases the burden on the physics engine.

That's a good point about the valve not staying in place. In practice, it should be fine for it to move back since the plugin will already have unlocked the door by that point. I'm afraid of increasing the friction too much and making it too hard to turn, but I'll try to increase it a little bit anyway.
content.html:
About moving the models around, it should be fine, because competitors are not expected to do this during the competition. The models which are not responding to gravity have been marked as "static". This means the robot can't knock them over, and it also eases the burden on the physics engine.

That's a good point about the valve not staying in place. In practice, it should be fine for it to move back since the plugin will already have unlocked the door by that point. I'm afraid of increasing the friction too much and making it too hard to turn, but I'll try to increase it a little bit anyway.

content.raw:
Other minor problems I noticed (which may or may not matter):

* If I move the habitat around, the door doesn't move with it.
* If I move the habitat around, the table (with the tools) stay fixed in place.  Indeed, physics doesn't seem to apply at all to the table, as running the simulation from that point doesn't make it fall to the ground.  Should we apply gravity to the table, and/or attach it to the habitat?
* The valve on the door doesn't seems to have a low amount of friction.  If I apply a lot of torque to it, it spins all the way to its "stop", and then starts spinning back the other way.  The valves for the satellite dish are similar.
content.html:
Other minor problems I noticed (which may or may not matter):

  • If I move the habitat around, the door doesn't move with it.
  • If I move the habitat around, the table (with the tools) stay fixed in place. Indeed, physics doesn't seem to apply at all to the table, as running the simulation from that point doesn't make it fall to the ground. Should we apply gravity to the table, and/or attach it to the habitat?
  • The valve on the door doesn't seems to have a low amount of friction. If I apply a lot of torque to it, it spins all the way to its "stop", and then starts spinning back the other way. The valves for the satellite dish are similar.

content.raw: No problem, this happens all the time to me too.
content.html: No problem, this happens all the time to me too.

content.raw: OK, I see what you mean from the rules.  I guess that's to make it easier, though less realistic.  Thanks for explaining.
content.html: OK, I see what you mean from the rules. I guess that's to make it easier, though less realistic. Thanks for explaining.

content.raw: Yeah, that's fine, as long as we are tracking it.  Thanks!
content.html: Yeah, that's fine, as long as we are tracking it. Thanks!

content.raw: I'll ping Cole about this, I imagine all it will require is changes in the texture coordinates on the obj file. We can always make a new PR for those later if we don't want this PR to be blocked.
content.html: I'll ping Cole about this, I imagine all it will require is changes in the texture coordinates on the obj file. We can always make a new PR for those later if we don't want this PR to be blocked.

content.raw:
Yeah I thought the same... But he [rules](https://ninesights.ninesigma.com/documents/15108047/0/Rules+-+rev+4.11.17/e10b9850-952e-4495-82e4-e874e5596a13) mention only one door. Also, I think it's quite dangerous to leave the door open behind you, but there's no checkpoint for closing the door...

But note that we're only considering checkpoint 3 (pass through the door) complete once the robot is all the way inside the habitat ([tutorial](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/finals_task3)).
content.html:
Yeah I thought the same... But he rules mention only one door. Also, I think it's quite dangerous to leave the door open behind you, but there's no checkpoint for closing the door...

But note that we're only considering checkpoint 3 (pass through the door) complete once the robot is all the way inside the habitat (tutorial).

content.raw: Ah, never mind!  I messed up regenerating unique.world, so it was always in exactly the same spot.  This is fine, sorry for the noise.
content.html: Ah, never mind! I messed up regenerating unique.world, so it was always in exactly the same spot. This is fine, sorry for the noise.

content.raw:
HEY! No fair making this harder!!

Ah, that's a big airlock that acts like a 'mud room' where they get the dust off everything. Yeah, yeah, that's the ticket. (Old Saturday Night Live punch line, there.)
content.html:
HEY! No fair making this harder!!

Ah, that's a big airlock that acts like a 'mud room' where they get the dust off everything. Yeah, yeah, that's the ticket. (Old Saturday Night Live punch line, there.)

content.raw:
How random is the leak location supposed to be?  In my limited playing around with it, it always seemed to be near the back airlock, approximately table height (see screenshot).  I didn't measure (I don't know how to do that in Gazebo), but it always seemed to be in roughly the same spot.  Is there something I need to do to randomize it, or is that expected?

![src-leak-position.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1290631367-src-leak-position.png)
content.html: How random is the leak location supposed to be? In my limited playing around with it, it always seemed to be near the back airlock, approximately table height (see screenshot). I didn't measure (I don't know how to do that in Gazebo), but it always seemed to be in roughly the same spot. Is there something I need to do to randomize it, or is that expected?

content.raw: In a nitpick, those NASA logos seem stretched in width, but don't maintain their aspect ratio.  Is there an easy way to fix that?
content.html: In a nitpick, those NASA logos seem stretched in width, but don't maintain their aspect ratio. Is there an easy way to fix that?

content.raw: This may be a dumb question, but wouldn't that habitat_door need to have an airlock?  That is, wouldn't there have to be a second door on the inside?
content.html: This may be a dumb question, but wouldn't that habitat_door need to have an airlock? That is, wouldn't there have to be a second door on the inside?

content.raw: Yes, that appears to work, the stairs and path outside are now the same color as the rest of the path in the world.
content.html: Yes, that appears to work, the stairs and path outside are now the same color as the rest of the path in the world.

content.raw: Understood! Thanks! I will update to the task3 branch to try our task3 worlds next time I get some time.
content.html: Understood! Thanks! I will update to the task3 branch to try our task3 worlds next time I get some time.

content.raw:
After a talk with @iche033, we came to the conclusion that a spot light pointing from the entrance door to the inside could be a good compromise. It doesn't light up the stairs area, and only leaks to the floor and behind the habitat. Implemented on cd8ef1f , let me know what you think.

![spot.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1663818236-spot.png)
content.html: After a talk with @iche033, we came to the conclusion that a spot light pointing from the entrance door to the inside could be a good compromise. It doesn't light up the stairs area, and only leaks to the floor and behind the habitat. Implemented on cd8ef1f , let me know what you think.

content.raw:
# UPDATE

Merged with default and now that pull request #52 has been merged we have a leak. So:

* Placed the leak on the habitat's wall randomly
* Removed the leak's visual (on the left panel, right-click the leak and choose view->collision)
* Made it a bit smaller

content.raw: Hi @aricstewart , thanks for trying this out. I didn't add a `unique_task3.world` to this pull request on purpose not to make it too long. This is already working on branch `task3` from pull request #57 though.
content.html: Hi @aricstewart , thanks for trying this out. I didn't add a unique_task3.world to this pull request on purpose not to make it too long. This is already working on branch task3 from pull request #57 though.

content.raw:
Humm that's an interesting idea. It looks like the sun is in fact leaking through the habitat*, so if we turn up the sun a bit, it might be bright enough inside, but that also affects the outside.

\* I suppose that's because the habitat is not receiving shadows
content.html:
Humm that's an interesting idea. It looks like the sun is in fact leaking through the habitat*, so if we turn up the sun a bit, it might be bright enough inside, but that also affects the outside.

* I suppose that's because the habitat is not receiving shadows

content.raw: How about changing it to a directional light, since those do cast shadows?
content.html: How about changing it to a directional light, since those do cast shadows?

content.raw:
Ah good point, I forgot about that. This is due to [Gazebo issue 2083](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2083/point-and-spot-lights-dont-cast-shadows). So the answer is: not desired, but expected. 

I'm trying to think of a way around it, but besides removing the habitat's roof I can't think of anything right now.
content.html:
Ah good point, I forgot about that. This is due to Gazebo issue 2083. So the answer is: not desired, but expected.

I'm trying to think of a way around it, but besides removing the habitat's roof I can't think of anything right now.

content.raw: It is also worth noting that the light inside of the habitat is changing the spectral properties of the models outside of the habitat.  I do not know if it is expected or desired for that to happen.
content.html: It is also worth noting that the light inside of the habitat is changing the spectral properties of the models outside of the habitat. I do not know if it is expected or desired for that to happen.

content.raw:
You cannot generate just a task 3 world with this code right now. 

I am not a ruby coder but here is a quick fix:


```
#!ruby


diff -r f9a1ddc76bbf worlds/unique.world.erb
--- a/worlds/unique.world.erb	Thu Apr 06 19:21:14 2017 -0700
+++ b/worlds/unique.world.erb	Mon Apr 10 20:18:39 2017 -0500
@@ -777,17 +777,34 @@
     </plugin>

     <!-- Walkway -->
-    <%=
-      t3cp1_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp2_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp3_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp5_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp7_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp8_frame = t2cp6_frame
+    <%
+      if (task == '0')
+    %>

-      # Can't have 90 degrees near the final box
-      nextWalkway($walkways, true)
-    %>
+        <%=
+          t3cp1_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp2_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp3_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp5_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp7_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp8_frame = t2cp6_frame
+
+          # Can't have 90 degrees near the final box
+          nextWalkway($walkways, true)
+        %>
+    <% else %>
+        <%=
+          t3cp1_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp2_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp3_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp5_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp7_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp8_frame = t3start_frame
+
+          # Can't have 90 degrees near the final box
+          nextWalkway($walkways, true)
+        %>
+    <% end %>

     <!-- Walkway -->
     <%=

```
content.html:
You cannot generate just a task 3 world with this code right now.

I am not a ruby coder but here is a quick fix:

diff -r f9a1ddc76bbf worlds/unique.world.erb
--- a/worlds/unique.world.erb   Thu Apr 06 19:21:14 2017 -0700
+++ b/worlds/unique.world.erb   Mon Apr 10 20:18:39 2017 -0500
@@ -777,17 +777,34 @@
     </plugin>

     <!-- Walkway -->
-    <%=
-      t3cp1_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp2_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp3_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp5_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp7_frame = t2cp6_frame
-      t3cp8_frame = t2cp6_frame
+    <%
+      if (task == '0')
+    %>

-      # Can't have 90 degrees near the final box
-      nextWalkway($walkways, true)
-    %>
+        <%=
+          t3cp1_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp2_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp3_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp5_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp7_frame = t2cp6_frame
+          t3cp8_frame = t2cp6_frame
+
+          # Can't have 90 degrees near the final box
+          nextWalkway($walkways, true)
+        %>
+    <% else %>
+        <%=
+          t3cp1_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp2_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp3_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp5_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp7_frame = t3start_frame
+          t3cp8_frame = t3start_frame
+
+          # Can't have 90 degrees near the final box
+          nextWalkway($walkways, true)
+        %>
+    <% end %>

     <!-- Walkway -->
     <%=

update.description:
Add habitat model for task 3 and integrate it into the world.

![hab1.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/2915144268-hab1.png)

* There's a habitat SDF model mostly for reference and to have the model directory structure
* The `habitat.erb` file is where the collisions and the whole model structure are actually generated from
* Detailed simple collision shapes for the stairs and rails
* Simple collision shapes for floors and walls

    ![hab2.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1709277528-hab2.png)

* There are two models, the `habitat_base` is a static model consisting of all the visuals except for the entrance door

* The `habitat_door` model is not static and consists of the door and the valve. It has 3 joints:
    * A fixed "lock" joint which will be removed once the valve is turned
    * A revolute joint for the valve, with the same range of friction as the satellite wheels

        ![habdoor.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/743741129-habdoor.gif)

    * A hinge joint with the world about which the door opens. If you want to try pushing the door, you can manually remove the lock joint from the world. The friction on the hinge helps the door remain open.

        ![habdoor2.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3570344327-habdoor2.gif)

        I tried pushing it with Val and it looks reasonable:

        ![habdoor4.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1139374490-habdoor4.gif)

* Moved the table to be inside the habitat and added a point light inside so it's not very dark:

    ![hab6.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3009515305-hab6.png)

* Modified the heightmap so that there's room for the habitat (humans are always changing planets, right?)
update.title: Task 3: Habitat model
